intro: Lessingia occidentalis, commonly known as the western eveningflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes mustard plants, and is characterized by its small, white or pink flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and coastal areas. It has hairy stems and leaves, and its flowers bloom in the late afternoon, hence its common name. Lessingia occidentalis is valued for its ecological role in supporting pollinators and its adaptability to arid environments.
